data.title: Oliver Parker (1733-abt.1818)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Oliver Parker born 1733 Groton, Middlesex, Massachusetts Bay died 1818 Brooksville, Hancock, Massachusetts, United States including ancestors + descendants + 1 genealogist comments + questions + Y-chromosome DNA + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 22 Aug 2023 | Created 11 Dec 2018

This page has been accessed 545 times.

Biography

Oliver Parker was a United Empire Loyalist.

UEL Status:Undetermined

Date: Undated

Oliver Parker; b. 15 Oct 1733[1] at Groton, Middlesex,Massachusetts; m. Eunice Farnsworth circa 1759; d. 1818 at Brooksville, Mass (Now Maine).

In the "History of Castine, Penobscot, and Brooksville, Maine:..."[2](Page 216 in particular), Oliver figures prominently. That gives his birthdate and place as Worcester 1738, which must be in error. There are too many overlaps with this Oliver for it not to be him. The marriage of his daughters to Wasson's, the number of children, that these children - identified as born in Groton - are all marrying in the area, and so forth all serve to link this Oliver to the one born in Groton in 1733.

That states that he was a loyalist, appointed as a Justice of the Peace for Worcester County by King George, who moved to St. John, New Brunswick for about 10 years, during the revolution, where he was engaged in mercantile business. He moved to Castine (Maine - at the time still Massachusetts) in 1784. At the first town meeting in 1787 and for several subsequent years, he was chosen selectman. He was elected Deacon in 1798, but declined the job the following year. In 1801 he was charged with misappropriation of funds in his own courthouse, although that does not seem to have gone anywhere.

"Judge Parker was twice married, and brought up a family of three sons and four daughters. Two of the latter married John and Samuel Wasson, of Brooksvile".[2]

He died in Brooksville in 1818.[2]

A Book search for Oliver Parker in Maine yields a number of other Oliver Parkers post 1818, primarily in Frankfort Maine, not far away. These would appear to be in reference to his son "v." below.

A preview of "The Essex Genealogist" Volumes 14-15 - Page 167 reads: "Oliver Parker was cashiered for defrauding his men of their wages by false returns, imposing on the commissary and drawing supplies for more men than were in ... Oliver and which was the loyalist who moved to NH, New Brunswick and Maine." It is unclear whether this is a treatise comparing the two Olivers or a reference to this one. A lookup of this reference would be helpful.

He is confused at present with Oliver Parker. It should be noted that that Oliver had 11 children with Jane Nutting.

Known children of Oliver Parker and Eunice Farnsworth all b. at Groton, Middlesex, Massachusetts, were as follows:

i. Rebecca Parker; b. 22 Nov 1760[3]; m. David Hawes circa 1780; d. 23 Nov 1833 at Brooksville, Hancock, Maine, at age 73.

ii. Eunice Parker; b. 11 Dec 1761[4]; m. John Seaton Wasson, son of John Joseph Wasson and Martha Seaton, 7 Nov 1782 at Nelson, Cheshire, New Hampshire; d. 9 Oct 1849 at Brooksville, Hancock, Maine, at age 87; Æ 87ys 10ms; she was buried at Mount Rest Cemetery, North Brooksville, Hancock, Maine.

iii. Elizabeth Parker; b. 23 Sep 1763[5]; m. Samuel Wasson, son of John Joseph Wasson and Martha Seaton, 14 Jun 1784 at Penobscot, Hancock, Maine; d. 5 Oct 1798 at Penobscot, Hancock, Maine, at age 35; she was buried at Mount Rest Cemetery, Brooksville, Hancock, Maine.

iv. Simeon Parker; b. 4 May 1765[6] at Groton, Middlesex, Massachusetts; m. Mary Perkins, daughter of Joseph Perkins and Phebe Weare, 20 Dec 1787; d. 5 May 1807 at Hancock, Maine, at age 42.

v. Oliver Parker; b. 4 Feb 1767; m. Joanna Higgins 21 Nov 1813 at Penobscot, Hancock, Maine; m. Sally Avery (b. 2 Apr 1797), daughter of Thatcher Avery and Hannah Atkins, 22 Apr 1818 at Castine, Hancock, Maine; m. Abigail McIntyre 29 Sep 1822 at Penobscot, Hancock, Maine.

PARKER, OLIVER.

Oliver Parker was of English descent, and was born in Worcester, Massachusetts, about the year 1738. He was appointed a Justice of the Peace for Worcester County, by King George, shortly after he had attained his majority. During the war of the Revolution, he was an active loyalist. 'He became very offensive to his neighbors, in consequence of his adherence to the Crown of England, and was, on this account, obliged to leave his native country, when peace was declared. He went to St. John, New Brunswick, where he resided some ten years. While there, he was engaged in mercantile business, and accumulated considerable property, which he is said to have lost through the dishonesty of his partner in business. Mr. Parker moved to Castine in 1794, and bought the farm now owned by Mr. Alexander G. Perkins. About the year 1800, he was appointed by Governor Strong, Judge of the Court of Common Pleas. This office he held nearly fifteen years. Judge Parker was much interested in religious matters, and was instrumental in having the meeting-house built at North Castine—then Penobscot. He was a member of Reverend Mr. Mason's church, and, for a short time, was one of the deacons. From 1787 to 1790, and again in 1792, he was chosen one of the Board of Selectmen of Penobscot. It is related of him, that, being inveigled by others into some iniquitous transaction, he was brought as a prisoner before the bar of the very Court over which he had once presided. The finding of the Court in his case we do not know ; but it is claimed that whatever this may have been, he was free from intentional wrong-doing. Judge Parker was twice married, and brought up a family of three sons and four daughters. Two of the latter married John and Samuel Wasson, of Brooksville. Judge Parker died in Brooksville, in the year 1818, aged about eighty years.
